body: Fix for [OPTIQ-269] - see comments above
Fixed in https://github.com/apache/incubator-optiq/commit/f247bc610f8b8ddfd657e7a4dc00ea2e32fe9bed.

I added a test to JdbcTest.java:

``` java
  /** Query that reads no columns from either underlying table. */
  @Test public void testCountStar() {
    OptiqAssert.that()
        .with(OptiqAssert.Config.REGULAR)
        .query("select count(*) c from \"hr\".\"emps\", \"hr\".\"depts\"")
        .convertContains("xxx");
  }
```

With your change:

```
AggregateRel(group=[{}], C=[COUNT()])
  ProjectRel(DUMMY=[0])
    JoinRel(condition=[true], joinType=[inner])
      EnumerableTableAccessRel(table=[[hr, emps]])
      EnumerableTableAccessRel(table=[[hr, depts]])
```

Without your change:

```
AggregateRel(group=[{}], C=[COUNT()])
  ProjectRel(DUMMY=[0])
    JoinRel(condition=[true], joinType=[inner])
      ProjectRel
        EnumerableTableAccessRel(table=[[hr, emps]])
      ProjectRel
        EnumerableTableAccessRel(table=[[hr, depts]])
```

Your plan is inferior -- the join thinks it needs to read all columns! Mine is a bit better. Ideal would be to add a dummy column as close to the leaves as possible:

```
AggregateRel(group=[{}], C=[COUNT()])
  JoinRel(condition=[true], joinType=[inner])
    ProjectRel(DUMMY=[0])
      EnumerableTableAccessRel(table=[[hr, emps]])
    ProjectRel(DUMMY=[0])
      EnumerableTableAccessRel(table=[[hr, depts]])
```
Doesn't work for us. If we don't have enough depth, the tags we need don't come through, and the git plugin fails.
Do you have any suggestions how to achieve what you are suggesting?

Oh.. Sorry missed your another commit. 
I see you made another commit fixing it differently. Cool.
okay
I used only the commit f12bb03 on my fork but it works as expected.

Hello Committers, 

Could you please review ?

I added a test for null values

``` java
    tester.checkNull("quarter(cast(null as date))");
```

and got an error. I think that if you change

``` java
    RexNode res =
        rexBuilder.makeCall(
            resType,
            SqlStdOperatorTable.EXTRACT_DATE,
            ImmutableList.of(rexBuilder.makeFlag(TimeUnitRange.MONTH), x));
```

and remote the `resType` argument it will correctly infer that the return type when applied to a nullable argument is a nullable BIGINT.

I also wanted to check whether the JDBC escape syntax works. I added

``` java
    tester.checkScalar("{fn QUARTER(DATE '1969-1-1')}", null, "");
```

and it failed. You need to add an entry to JdbcToInternalLookupTable.

The patch looks good, and we're close. Fix these two things and I will commit.

Looks good. I agree that getChildExps should go away, and we should make it deprecated now. Can you add "Will be removed before 1.0."

I believe deprecated stuff should survive at least a single release.
So we release 1.0 with this deprecated version and remove it in 1.1 or
later.

I do not think it makes sense to complicate migration to newer Calcite
versions without strong reason.

Regards,
Vladimir Sitnikov

We cant remove APIs in minor versions, only major versions. So its now or 2.0.

On Dec 13, 2014, at 1:34 PM, Vladimir Sitnikov notifications@github.com wrote:

> I believe deprecated stuff should survive at least a single release.
> So we release 1.0 with this deprecated version and remove it in 1.1 or
> later.
> 
> I do not think it makes sense to complicate migration to newer Calcite
> versions without strong reason.
> 
> Regards,
> Vladimir Sitnikov
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub.

Do you mean "either we remove APIs in 1.0 or we wait till 2.0"?

I do not think it is a good sign to drop non-deprecated APIs.
Well. "first apache version" is a bit different case.
However, I think we might need some policy regarding API changes.
I propose this as our policy: http://semver.org/.

When running on ubuntu host using vagrant 1.4.3 and VirtualBox 4.3.18_Ubuntu, I get the following error:

```
There are errors in the configuration of this machine. Please fix
the following errors and try again:

vm:
* The box 'puppetlabs/ubuntu-14.04-64-puppet' could not be found.
```

Any chance you upgrade to newer Vagrant? (1.7.0+)
It should resolve the issue. If that works, I can add `Vagrant.require_version ">= 1.7.0"`

As far as I understand, Vagrant 1.4.3 can install Ubuntu 12 boxes (precise64) from cloud, however I am not sure if we need to support and have that version as a main target.

Can you try adding `config.vm.box_url` line to Vagrantfile?

``` ruby
Vagrant.configure(2) do |config|
  config.vm.box = "puppetlabs/ubuntu-14.04-64-puppet"
  config.vm.box_url = "https://vagrantcloud.com/puppetlabs/boxes/ubuntu-14.04-32-puppet/versions/1/providers/virtualbox.box"

  config.vm.define :ubuntucalcite do |ubuntucalcite|
```

I'm using the version of vagrant that ubuntu installs automatically. I probably _could_ upgrade but I'm not sure that I _should_.

I'm having some luck with

```
config.vm.box_url = "https://vagrantcloud.com/puppetlabs/boxes/ubuntu-13.10-64-puppet/versions/0.2.0/providers/virtualbox.box"
```

Now running into

```
[ubuntucalcite] Clearing any previously set forwarded ports...
Vagrant cannot forward the specified ports on this VM, since they
would collide with some other application that is already listening
on these ports. The forwarded port to 27017 is already in use
on the host machine.

To fix this, modify your current projects Vagrantfile to use another
port. Example, where '1234' would be replaced by a unique host port:

  config.vm.network :forwarded_port, guest: 27017, host: 1234

Sometimes, Vagrant will attempt to auto-correct this for you. In this
case, Vagrant was unable to. This is usually because the guest machine
is in a state which doesn't allow modifying port forwarding.
```

I wonder if it's because I have MongoDB, MySQL, Postgres running on the host machine.
Nice work. Once you've fixed a few review comments, +1 to check in.

> I wonder if it's because I have MongoDB, MySQL, Postgres running on the
> host machine.

I believe that is the case.
Did you resolve the problem?

Vladimir

There's already a SetOpFactory that can create union, intersect, minus. To create a union, you just need to pass in SqlKind.UNION as the first argument. Can you use that please?
Thanks @julianhyde , I changed the code to use SetOpFactory instead.

Note that you can chain metadata providers. So, you _could_ create say HiveRelMdMemory, a metadata provider that implements methods for Hive relational expressions, and chain it with RelMdMemory, the metadata provider that implements the core relational expressions.

However, sub-classing is also reasonable, so I'll accept this pull request.

@julianhyde , it seems the change in the method changed its expected behavior. Thus, I have created a new method that will create a different type of mapping and that is used uniquely by RelMdDistribution, and I left the original method as it was.

Hi, can you please add the test case to validate the change?

Here's the way to prepare VM for tests: https://github.com/apache/incubator-calcite/blob/master/doc/HOWTO.md#running-integration-tests
Closing as the PR was already merged in

I don't think it would do the right thing on this query:

``` sql
select deptno
from EMP
where deptno > (select min(deptno) * 2 + 10 from EMP group by gender)
```

or this:

``` sql
select deptno
from EMP
where deptno > (values 10)
```

In your javadoc can you explain what you mean by "scalar"?

Or this:

``` sql
select deptno
from EMP
where deptno > (select deptno * 2 + 10 from EMP order by deptno limit 1)
```

First of all, in the javadoc, scalar refers to a single value. For example, 1 is while [1, 2, 3] is not.

For query 1, the subquery will return a non-scalar. So it is reasonable for the plan to contain a single value function like below, right? (notice because there is no "gender" this column in the table, I substituted it with "empno" in your original query.)

LogicalProject(DEPTNO=[$7])
  LogicalFilter(condition=[>($7, $9)])
    LogicalJoin(condition=[true], joinType=[left])
      LogicalTableScan(table=[[CATALOG, SALES, EMP]])
      LogicalAggregate(group=[{}], agg#0=[SINGLE_VALUE($0)])
        LogicalProject(EXPR$0=[+(*($1, 2), 10)])
          LogicalAggregate(group=[{0}], agg#0=[MIN($1)])
            LogicalProject(EMPNO=[$0], DEPTNO=[$7])
              LogicalTableScan(table=[[CATALOG, SALES, EMP]])

For query 2, you are right. The current patch is not able to respond properly. I already had a fix.

For query 3, it is the LIMIT which makes the subquery return a scalar. I am working on it now.

While you are working on the fix, please think carefully. Your first patch added a feature but introduced an obvious bug. If you are not 100% safe to remove the SINGLE_VALUE function in a particular query you should not do it.
Sorry to quibble, but a list with one element is not scalar. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalar

You removed the indentation -- can you restore it?

Also please restore the MySQL URL to localhost. (It's just an example, so let's use the simplest thing.)

And please use null rather than the CATALOG variable.
Merge with pull request #88

> This change means that the client has to make an extra round-trip in order to create a statement before they prepare-and-execute. Why is this necessary?

Before this change, the client already making the round-trip, the statement was created during createStatement() RPC call, here it reuse the cached statement. If not, the statement being created is not use, and at RemoteMeta, the statement id is also get out of sync if preparedAndExecute recreate the statement again.

> Check for < 0, not == -1.

We discussed this before in 712~~708~~, as you pointed out, in meta maxRowCount == 0 is not same as JDBC statement.setMaxRows(0). So, here for JDBC meta, there's no handling for 0 as 0 means different in meta. Below, it actually handles it as it will fetch 0 row.

> You can also note that maxRowCount == 0 is not handled. (I.e. there is a bug in this code) but you don't need to fix it.

As above comment, the maxRowCount == 0 is handled in JdbcResultSet set, where it  does not get any row, and close the resultSet. As meta maxRowCount == 0 means 0 row

Pull request looks pretty good. I have re-worked what you have done:
- rebased onto master,
- some cleanup,
- made createTable return a Table, not a TableEntry, so it becomes the caller's job to choose a name and register it in a schema,
- remove suggested name from TableFactory interface, and carry it along as a separate parameter. Now TableFactory can be a field in MaterializationService, because it is not specific to one table.

This is all in my branch https://github.com/julianhyde/incubator-calcite/tree/table_factory. Can you please review and let me know whether they work for your purpose.

Tested. It works for me.

@vlsi , I have addressed your comments in the new pull request. Thanks

Hi Julian,

I changed the code based on your comments. Pls see the following response. 

(I squash the two commits into one. Not sure if that's OK or not for the pull request).

1 . In misc.oq, a field that was called "DESC" is now called "EXPR$1". Can you restore the old name?

[jni]  I guess you are talking about the JdbcTest.testInnerJoinValues(), where "DESC" is changed to "EXPR$1".  

Actually, the field name change happens only in EXPLAIN PLAN output;  the query result is still using "DESC".  I spent quite some time trying to figure out why the field name is changed in EXPLAIN.  I do not have a completely clear idea why it happened. But seems Calcite put two RelNodes with different rowType under the same RelSet.   The following is from the calcite trace "before" my code change: 

Set#1, type: RecordType(INTEGER EXPR$0, CHAR(8) EXPR$1)
  rel#11:Subset#1.NONE.[], best=null, importance=0.5904900000000001
    rel#1:LogicalValues.NONE.[[0, 1], [1]](type=RecordType%28INTEGER EXPR$0, CHAR%288%29 EXPR$1%29,tuples=[{ 10, 'SameName' }]), rowcount=1.0, cumulative cost={inf}
    rel#12:LogicalProject.NONE.[[0, 1], [1]](input=rel#11:Subset#1.NONE.[],ID=$0,DESC=$1), rowcount=1.0, cumulative cost={inf}

In the above, the LogicalValues has (EXPR$0, EXPR$1), LogicalProject has (ID, DESC). Yet Calcite still put them together under the same RelSet.  My guess is CALCITE-457 patch will impact the order of some rules firing, and somehow the rowType of downstream RelNode is messed up.

On the other hand, I think Calcite's API does not guarantee that the intermediate RelNode will keep the same field name;  the output field name is ensured to be same via validator.getValidatedNodeType(). That's why the query result still has "DESC" in the output. Therefore, I feel it might be ok to have different field name in the EXPLAIN plan output.

Another comment : this testcase does not have the join condition pushed. That's simply because of costing.  Values() has one row only.  I tried with two rows, and verified the condition will be pushed. 
1. It's appropriate to always create a LogicalJoin when in SqlToRelConverter, less so in general-purpose planner rules. Can you use a join factory and not add method RelOptUtil.createJoin?

[jni] 
I tried to add join factory to FilterJoinRule, that seems require more change.  In stead, I chose to passing in originalJoin, and use join.copy() method. That way, in the general-purpose planner rule or SqlToRelConverter, the new created Join will be of the same class of original join node. 
1. [jni] Now I pass in param originalJoin. No need for such format.  
2. join.oq should end with newline
   [jni]  Done. 
3. Can you add a test for FilterJoinRule's new capability to RelOptRulesTest.
   [jni] testPushJoinCondDownToProject() is Added.
This change is by Venki Korukanti, correct? I want to give credit in the commit message.

Yes, that's why I keep the author as Venki in the commit . My understanding is if you merge this PR, it will keep the authorship ( there seems no need to put the author info in the commit msg, since git will take care of that). 

Commit: 7c3d6543be8e5223e63ce1a0137014446cd63dc5 [7c3d654]
Parents: dbdb091dc6
Author: vkorukanti venki.korukanti@gmail.com
We have a policy of putting the author in the commit message for all non-committers. Because not all commits arrive as PRs.
This looks really good. And I appreciate that you added testTwoLattices. But the test suite runs long and runs out of memory -- probably due to that test. Will need to fix before we check in.

Glad you are seeing this too. Runtime varies a bit - between 3 min and
never finish on my vbox just for this test. The inefficiency is worse in
the app using calcite. I have setup 6 lattices and every query ends up
trying to use all the tiles from all the lattices. Mainly because all of
them use date_dim or some dimension table that occurs in a majority of
queries.

The problem is in the VolcanoPlanner. Is there something more intelligent I
can do ? For e.g. choose materializations that are tiles only if the fact
table is used here (
https://github.com/apache/incubator-calcite/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/plan/volcano/VolcanoPlanner.java#L445
).

I dont completely understand the implications of that change.

In addition to "suggestedTableName" there is a "schema" argument. I think that comes from the schema where the materialized view is defined, so if you define the index / materialized view in the same schema as the base table, I think you're good.

I've started work on a test case for this. I won't check in unless we have covering tests.
It's this extra sort, looks like the result with Materialization is not in the right order. But you are right, I shouldn't have removed it.

Hi Julian,
I have take care of all your comments.
MVSubstitutionVisitor has been added old rules of substitution, thus we can only use the new visitor now.

However, we did not see any test failures (not just me but even others who are using this code in our fork). But if the test is still failing for you, then we can @Ignore it as it only depicts false positive which can be worked on and not the false negative. 

Thanks,
Amogh
